subject: RE: [junit] Something is bothering me about assumptions
msgSnippet: Charlie, I think it is reasonable to ask that a test with an assumption fail (or at least be marked ignored) if *all* the test data fails the assumption.  A
messageBody:
Charlie,


I think it is reasonable to ask that a test with an assumption fail (or at least be marked ignored) if *all* the test data fails the assumption. A test that never executes because its assumption is never satisfied is counterproductive. In this case, a failure would alert the user could fix the assumption, update the test data, or remove the test entirely if it's no longer needed.



Rocco



From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Charlie Poole
Sent: Thursday, February 11, 2010 2:28 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Something is bothering me about assumptions





It seems to me that the behavior you are asking for is appropriate
if an assumption fails in a normal test as opposed to a theory.

Charlie

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com<mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com<mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>] On
> Behalf Of Berin
> Sent: Tuesday, February 09, 2010 2:29 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com<mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [junit] Something is bothering me about assumptions
>
> I've seen in a few places that if an assumption fails, the
> test automatically passes. I then ran into the test case
> that confirms that action. Coming from the aspect that I
> want to have confidence that my code and tests are
> functioning properly, I honestly think that is the wrong action.
>
> If an assumption is violated then it should be either a
> failure or at best ignored. To say the test passes because
> something failed is like saying you don't have a cavity
> because the dentist doesn't have the right tool. You don't
> know one way or the other, and the test won't be able to run
> properly when the assumption is violated.
>
> It's partly that reason that I don't use assumptions to begin
> with. If there needs to be a certain precondition to the
> test passing, I will add those assertions before I perform
> the action that needs to be tested. To me, it is a failure
> if the test could not be set up properly.
>
> If you want something a little softer, then I recommend that
> a failed assumption is equivalent to the @Ignore annotation.
> You'll see in the summary that X number of tests were run, Y
> number of tests ignored, and Z number of tests failed.
> Although, for ignored tests I'd like to see what the reason
> was (failed assumption or manually ignored through the attribute).
>
> Making a test pass because of a failed assumption gives you a
> false sense of security about your code. What is happening
> is that the test just wasn't run, and there may be a
> legitimate problem hiding. To me that is the most dangerous
> part of that solution. I'd rather get the bad news straight
> than trust faulty information.
>
> Am I making sense?
>
